It can be seen that average second job income is the same for married men employees as for all self-employed. The higher percentage of second job income is thus partly because our estimate of main job income is much lower for the self-employed. Our income data for the self-employed are probably of poor quality.

One method of income tax collection on second jobs adopted by the Inland Revenue is to adjust the PAYE code used in the main job downwards. Actual and estimated PAYE codes are discussed in Brown et al (1982c).
A non-standard PAYE code signals that special arrangements apply for income tax collection; for example, with a BR code all income is taxed at the basic rate.

Occasional second jobs have been excluded from the analysis.

Strictly any job which pays more than the Lower Earnings Limit (LEL) is subject to National Insurance contributions. The definition of evasion therefore would be if somebody earned more than the LEL on their second job and did not pay NI contributions on that job. It is true that if total contributions from both jobs exceed an annual maximum there is a (normally automatic) refund at the end of the tax year but it is not for workers to anticipate this by not paying contributions on current earnings where these combined earnings exceed the UEL in any week!
CSO op. cit.

If pay was unusual in the last pay period, the cumulative nature of the PAYE system could result in a respondent legitimately paying no income tax although he appears to be above the tax threshold for that week.
